channel.title: Comments on: How To Name Default Constraints And How To Drop Default Constraint Without A Name In SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: SQL Server – alter column – adding default constraint | Zepka Answers
item.dc:creator: SQL Server – alter column – adding default constraint | Zepka Answers
item.description: […] also make certain we name a default constraint..it will be a pain in a neck to dump it after since it will have one of those crazy component generated names…see also How To Name Default Constraints And How To Drop Default Constraint Without A Name In SQL Server […]
item.content:encoded: […] also make certain we name a default constraint..it will be a pain in a neck to dump it after since it will have one of those crazy component generated names…see also How To Name Default Constraints And How To Drop Default Constraint Without A Name In SQL Server […]

item.title: By: Erik Easton
item.dc:creator: Erik Easton
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for this!
Only I found using:
> where s.xtype = ‘d’
revealed zero results, but using:
> where s.xtype = ‘D’
worked.

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.description: Thanks, this helped me to come up with a script to drop default constraints for the columns in a table because I needed to change type from image to varbinary(max) and was getting errors because of default constraints. I had to get rid of them first.
item.content:encoded: Thanks, this helped me to come up with a script to drop default constraints for the columns in a table because I needed to change type from image to varbinary(max) and was getting errors because of default constraints. I had to get rid of them first.
